paragraphs.text: No, because TypeScript will only tell you if you passed an invalid set of props to you component, not which valid one you expected.

370a7f553d14.title: Anyone testing a react component should know about Jason Quense’s teaspoon (https://github.com…

paragraphs.name: 6c79
paragraphs.text: Anyone testing a react component should know about Jason Quense’s teaspoon (https://github.com/jquense/teaspoon) it is a lifesaver for writing tests that only test one thing so that changing one element doesn’t blow up every unit test. After all, the primary purpose of tests is not to verify correctness now, but later when you need to change the code.

f8904a3fa261.title: I don’t want to mount the lockscreen in the top-level beforeEach, because I want child beforeEaches…

paragraphs.name: c464
paragraphs.text: I don’t want to mount the lockscreen in the top-level beforeEach, because I want child beforeEaches to be able to change the props before I mount it. If you mount it and then change the props, you have to remount it or use setProps. So I delay mounting it until test execution, so that all the beforeEach callbacks can run first.

paragraphs.name: fd42
paragraphs.text: Nice writeup! The rules you have crystalized are what I follow as well. I generally have a utility function at the top of my test const shallowRender = (props) => shallow(<Component {...props} />); and then just call it in each test passing the exact prop I want to i.e shallowRender({ someProp: 'test' }); I would also have a similar function for…
